resources.string: Kenneth Thompson (New Orleans, February 4, 1943) is a factor scientist, known for its influence on the creation of the UNIX operating system, for the invention of the B programming language, predecessor of the C programming language. Originally hired in 1966 to work on the Bell Labs Multics project, Thompson met Dennis Ritchie and studied together with Ritchie to create the UNIX operating system. Thompson also created a B programming language, a precursor to Dennis Ritchie\'s C language. Thompson is also known for other works, such as the Plan 9 operating system. his contributions in defining UTF-8 character classification, final tables, and the Belle chess machine. Since 2006, he has been working at Google, where he co-invented a Go programming language.

Brian Kernighan (Toronto, 1942) is a Canadian computer scientist. He worked at Bell Laboratories and contributed in pioneering work to the development of the programming languages ​​AWK and AMPL. Brian Kernighan\'s name became known for co-authoring the first book on the C programming language with Dennis Ritchie. Kernighan reportedly said that he did not contribute to the development of the C language: \"It was all Dennis Ritchie\'s work.\" He has authored several UNIX programs, including ditroff. He was born in Toronto, Canada, and completed his Bachelor\'s Degree in \"Physical Engineering\" at the University of Toronto. He obtained his PhD in Electrical Engineering at Princeton University, where since 2004 he has been a professor in the Department of Computer Science.
